title: Teen daughter stabs mum in chest and tells her 'I should have dug it in deeper'
text:

A mum-of-five was stabbed by her own teenage daughter who then shouted "I should have dug it in deeper", a court heard.

Paige Gaffney's mother forgave her and begged a judge not to jail her following the violent attack at their home in Scunthorpe, North Lincolnshire, in October 2017.

Gaffney was just 16 when she pulled her mum's hair and plunged a 7in kitchen knife into her chest from behind, the court heard.

The teen offered no help before her mum passed out as she bled on the kitchen floor, GrimsbyLive reports.

Gaffney, now 18, then kicked her mother twice in the head before wiping the knife clean and tossing it out of a bathroom window.

She has been spared jail for the attack after admitting wounding her mum, who suffered a one-inch cut to her liver.

(Image: Facebook)

Judge Mark Bury told her: "You are very lucky, as is your mother, that more serious harm was not caused. You could have killed her then you would have been facing a murder charge."

The judge said Gaffney had an unhappy childhood, adding: "Your mother and father had a toxic relationship and eventually split up. Your mother had a number of relationships that were not long in duration and each one resulted in your four siblings."

He added: "Your mother has had issues with drink and drugs and unsuitable relationships. That was something you resented."

Craig Lowe, prosecuting, told Grimsby Crown Court said the mother was cooking supper when she went to her daughter's bedroom and found her playing with razor blades.

After taking them from her, the mum was followed into the kitchen where Gaffney grabbed a 7in knife that her mother was using to chop vegetables.

Gaffney took the knife back to her room and she was followed by her mum, resulting in a heated row.

(Image: scunthorpetelegraph.co.uk)

The teen pulled her mother's hair and "plunged the knife into her mother's chest from behind," said Mr Lowe.

One of the mum's sons gave a towel to the injured woman, but Gaffney offered no assistance, the court heard.

Mr Lowe said the mother returned to the kitchen, sat on the floor and called a friend before passing out.

Gaffney then kicked her mother twice in the head and disposed of the knife.

When the mother was on the phone Gaffney shouted "I should have dug it in deeper", said Mr Lowe.

Gaffney lied to police, claiming her mother - who made a swift recovery - had stabbed herself.

In her victim impact statement, the mum told how she was desperate to have a relationship with her daughter again.

She said: "I just want to hug her. It is horrible not having contact. My life has gone downhill. The last two years have been horrible."

She added: "I have been asked if I want a restraining order. I said no and just want to hug her. I still love her and want her to get the help she needs."

Gaffney wept as the statement was read out in court.

Michele Stuart-Lofthouse, defending, said Gaffney had a "difficult family background" but had now found some stability after moving in with her partner and his family in Birmingham.

The judge told the court that Gaffney's mother did not want her to go to prison.

He said: "It may be she [the mother] is no role model, but that is no reason to behave like this. You blamed her. You said it was nothing to do with you. She is forgiving.

He added: "She wants a relationship with you and you with her and no doubt in time you will. That will depend on you showing everybody that you have changed.

"If she is able to forgive you for what you have done, you should be able to forgive her for the way she brought you up."

Gaffney was sentenced to 18 months in a young offenders' institution, suspended for 18 months,

She was ordered to complete 200 hours of unpaid work.
description: Paige Gaffney, who was 16 at the time of the attack, plunged a 7in kitchen knife into her mum's chest from behind in Scunthorpe, North Lincolnshire
